top_procedures.description: Nuclear medicine studies of blood flow in heart muscle at rest and with stress
Ultrasound examination of heart including color-depicted blood flow rate, direction, and valve function
Established patient office or other outpatient, visit typically 25 minutes
Ultrasound scanning of blood flow (outside the brain) on both sides of head and neck
Rubidium rb-82, diagnostic, per study dose, up to 60 millicuries
New patient office or other outpatient visit, typically 45 minutes
Nuclear medicine study of vessels of heart using drugs or exercise multiple studies
Routine ekg using at least 12 leads including interpretation and report
Insertion of catheter in left heart for imaging of blood vessels or grafts and left lower heart
Exercise or drug-induced heart and blood vessel stress test with ekg monitoring, physician supervision, interpretation, and report
Electrocardiogram (ecg) up to 30 days continuous with transmission of patient triggered events with review and report by health care professional
Established patient outpatient visit, total time 20-29 minutes
Injection, regadenoson, 0.1 mg
Subsequent hospital inpatient care, typically 25 minutes per day
Catheter placement of stents in major coronary artery or branch, accessed through the skin, each additional artery or branch
Initial hospital inpatient care, typically 50 minutes per day
Technetium tc-99m sestamibi, diagnostic, per study dose
Insertion of probe in esophagus for heart ultrasound examination including interpretation and report
Heart rhythm tracing, analysis, and interpretation of 48-hour ekg, includes recording, scanning analysis with report
Complete ultrasound of aorta, vena cava, groin vessels or bypass grafts
